dc:description:
The *XPNPEP3* gene is located on chromosome at 22q13.2 and encodes a member of the family of X-pro-aminopeptidases that utilize a metal cofactor and remove the N-terminal amino acid from peptides with a proline residue in the penultimate position. This protein has been shown to localize to the mitochondria of kidney cells and have a role in ciliary function. (provided by RefSeq, Mar 2011). 

*XPNPEP3* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Nephronophthisis-like Nephropathy 1 (NPHPL1) in 2010 (O'Toole et al. PMID: 20179356). The mechanism of disease is biallelic loss of function. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level, segregation, and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 6 probands in 5 publications (PMID: 29383790, 32660933,37599822,38035175, DOI: 10.1681/ASN.20233411S1571a). Unpublished data was included in this curation, a patient with a consistent phenotype associated with compound heterozygous null variants (Molecular Biology Laboratory, Fundació Puigvert and  submitted to ClinVar), increasing the final score by 3.0 points for a total of 11.3 genetic evidence points. 

This gene-disease association is supported by protein interaction, in vitro functional assays, and a zebrafish and a mouse model (PMID: 20179356, 37599822). There is significant correlation between β-catenin nuclear localization and XPNPEP3 levels, suggesting *XPNPEP3* has a role in Wnt-mediated regulation of ciliary development (Kumar et al. 2018; PMID: 29383790, non-scorable evidence).

In summary, there is Definitive evidence to support *XPNPEP3* as a cause of an autosomal recessive ciliopathy. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen Kidney Cystic and Ciliopathy Disorders GCEP on 04/28/2021 (SOP Version 8). It was reevaluated on 6/10/2024 (SOP Version 10). As a result of this reevaluation, the classification changed from Moderate to Definitive.
curationReasonDescription: A patient with consistent phenotypes and two compound heterozygous null variants submitted to ClinVar (Molecular Biology Laboratory, Fundació Puigvert), and a proband from Xunzi Tang et al., 2023 (DOI: 10.1681/ASN.20233411S1571a) with nephronophthisis and compound heterozygous for a missense and nonsense mutation were included in this curation. The genetic evidence increased by 4.6 points for a total of 14.3 points.

evidence.dc:description: Not enough affected individuals for LOD calculation
evidence.rdfs:label: F543

member.rdfs:label: F543 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and linkage analysis of 116 consanguineous families to find genomic segments in common. PCR and sequencing of candidate genes of affected individuals to compare to homozygosity mapping resulted in XPNPEP3. High resolution melting analysis to identify specific variants.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Increased echogenicity, mental developmental delay, RCC1 defect, ESRD by age 8/9, NPHP phenotypes in renal ultrasound and histology, mitochondriopathy, with an isolated complex I deficiency and decreased NADH-CoQ oxidoreductase activity, seizures, hypertrophic dilated cardiomyopathy, chronic pancreatitis with pancreatic cysts

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: ESRD by age 8/9, NPHP phenotypes in renal ultrasound and histology, mitochondriopathy, with an isolated complex I deficiency and decreased NADH-CoQ oxidoreductase activity, seizures, hypertrophic dilated cardiomyopathy, chronic pancreatitis with pancreatic cysts, II-2 had hepatopathy

evidence.rdfs:label: A131

member.rdfs:label: A313 II-4
member.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and linkage analysis of 116 consanguineous families to find genomic segments in common. PCR and sequencing of candidate genes of affected individuals to compare to homozygosity mapping resulted in XPNPEP3. High resolution melting analysis to identify specific variants.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Moderate renal insufficiency, increased echogenicity, hypertension, essential tremor, SNHL, muscle fatigue, gout, renal histology of A131 II-4: thickening, splitting, and attenuation of tubular basement membranes in tubules with disorganized epithelium, atrophic tubules that contain protein casts, dilated collecting ducts, which are lined by exceptionally tall epithelium, a mild degree of interstitial fibrosis (Fig. 2)

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Moderate renal insufficiency, increased echogenicity, hypertension, renal cysts in 2 of 3 affected family members, essential tremor, SNHL in 2/3 affected family members, gout in 2/3 affected family members, renal histology of A131 II-4: thickening, splitting, and attenuation of tubular basement membranes in tubules with disorganized epithelium, atrophic tubules that contain protein casts, dilated collecting ducts, which are lined by exceptionally tall epithelium, a mild degree of interstitial fibrosis (Fig. 2)

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient B - II-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: cystic foci, 22∗8 mm, were detected in the left ilium , at this age, his 24-h urine protein excretion was 0.32–0.48 g, and this increased to 1.3 g at 12 years of age. Hyperuricemia (408 μmol/L) and an elevation in serum cystatin C levels (1.23 mg/L, reference range 0.55–1.03 mg/L) were recorded recently

evidence.dc:description: This variant was not scored due to lack of functional evidence supporting pathogenicity and splice impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient A - II-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Kidney injury was identified in tubular epithelial cells from urine samples of patient A as biopsy/nephrectomy samples were unavailable. Compared to an age-matched control, the expression levels of kidney injury molecule 1 (KIM1) and neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) were higher.

evidence.dc:description: Patient-derived lymphoblasts carrying c.634G>A and c.761G>T together exhibit elevated mitochondrial XPNPEP3 levels via the reduction of mRNA degradation, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction in both urine tubular epithelial cells and lymphoblasts from patient.

Patient-derived lymphoblasts carrying c.634G>A and c.761G>T together exhibit elevated mitochondrial XPNPEP3 levels via the reduction of mRNA degradation, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction in both urine tubular epithelial cells and lymphoblasts from patient.

evidence.rdfs:label: Alizadeh Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Oligohydramnios at the third trimester of gestation, growth failure and anemia at 6 months age, polyurea and polydipsia as well as chronic kidney disease at 3rd years of age, increased parenchymal echogenicity, and the size of kidneys was within the lower limit of normal.

evidence.dc:description: Scored as null variant without supporting functional evidence. Downgraded for consanguinity.
Downgraded for consanguinity: only counted once, not twice
Variant is downgrade to 1.5pts due to possibility of consanguinity.
Downgraded for consanguinity: only counted once, not twice.

E.coli homolog XPNPEP3 efficiently cleaves 9–amino acid peptides identical to the N-termini of each of NPHP6, ALMS1, LRRC50. Does not cleave same peptides without N-terminal proline, poorly digests peptide with N-terminal proline but not involved in kidney disease. 
DNAAF1 (LRCC50) involved in ciliary development primarily in lungs not kidneys.
CEP290 = NPHP6
evidence.rdfs:label: O'Toole Protein Interaction Study

evidence.dc:description: KO of Xpnpep3−/− in vivo recapitulated the NPHPL-like phenotype with mitochondrial dysfunction and ciliary defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Xpnpep3-KO mice

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish model is not best suited to recapitulate kidney phenotypes, but Wnt signalling defects and situs inversus are recapitulated.

Quantifiable gastrulation defects reminiscent of ciliary gene morphants (due to involvement in Wnt signalling): shortened body axis, small anterior structures, broadening and kinking of the notochord, and elongated somites. Wnt signalling is a recognized abnormality in NPHP/ciliary diseases.
Situs inversus is seen in some patients with NPHP, but none of the patients in this curation.
evidence.rdfs:label: O'Toole Zebrafish Model
